Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Simplification AI for Workforce Upskilling
Award.AbstractNarration:
This STTR Phase I project addresses the challenge of upskilling the workforce by developing novel personalized content simplification technology. It will build a novel digital binder tool with an AI empowered content selection and simplification capability. The magnitude and urgency of the workforce upskilling problem require an immediate and robust solution. Corporations are desperate to find and nurture appropriately skilled workers to fill emerging roles. Beyond big high-tech corporations, the need for retraining is expanding in the trades and manufacturing space. An estimated 300-600 million people will need to be retrained between now and 2030.


The proposed breakthrough solution utilizes state-of-the-art deep learning and natural language processing algorithms to automatically generate training materials appropriate for the level of familiarity that trainees have with the content and skills they need to acquire. This is facilitated by three core technologies: a content simplification solution with the capability of searching and identifying collections of digital resources by identifying key concepts. The applied algorithms consider the current background of the learner and include documents needed to comprehend those key concepts. The second technology addresses the open problem of text simplification by proposing a hybrid approach of traditional text simplification techniques like word substitution and a novel information retrieval approach that identifies concepts critical for the comprehensibility of advanced documents. The third technology is a personalized content simplification engine tailored to the needs and capacities of each trainee who can continue to use the technology for continuous retraining, upskilling and lifelong learning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of  this  STTR project was to build a novel digital binder tool with an AI empowered content selection and simplification capability to support workforce upskilling and reskilling. The developed technology retrieves freely available resources on the training topic, and using deep learning and natural language processing techniques it detects concepts critical for the understanding of the training topic. The existing gaps that each trainee has are evaluated by Choosito?s existing adaptive learner model. The proposed content simplification solution is  an automated concept decomposition process that provides personalized resources to help the trainee engage with appropriate materials. The content is further simplified, when appropriate,  by rephrasing with simpler terms.

 

Specifically, the following research objectives have been completed: 

 

1) Resource Building Module Based on Topic-Keyword: 

The resource building module accepts a topic-keyword or phrase as the input. Using existing Choosito?s search technology,  documents are retrieved from the web or other available resources. Next, with the methodologies developed in this STTR project,   a list of documents is identified that are semantically related to the first retrieved documents. This approach is different from the typical keyword search because it retrieves not only documents that include the specific keyword but documents that are semantically related to the entire content of the target document. 

 

2) Leveled Retrieval of Semantically Related Documents:

For a given complex document, the task was to retrieve documents that are on the same topic but written at different complexity levels. This means that the document-level representation should be able to capture semantic similarity across levels.  This task was accomplished by fine-tuning a Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers model to learn complexity levels from a small number of annotated documents.

 

3) Concept Identification:

Beyond retrieving similar documents, a crucial step in this project  is identifying a document?s concepts. That is, given a document,  all concepts are extracted that are critical to understanding that document. This is a non-trivial task that will, however, enable predicting which concepts are familiar to the user and for which concepts the tool needs to provide further educational materials for study. This  problem was addressed  with a variety of methods for extracting candidates for key concepts and filtering them using models trained on existing online curricula. 

 

The outcome of this STTR Phase I project has resulted in the following tools:

 

1) Upskilled World: The development of a web-based prototype called ?Upskilled World?  has been completed. The tool  allows the user to search for topic of interest for upskilling/reskilling in the areas of computer science/technology, receive leveld results of  semantically related documents beyond keyword-based retrieval, interact with the automatically identified concepts in each document that are critical to understanding the reading, for each concept look up a definition, a summary or further readings, reject concepts that are already known and highlight unknown concepts that were missed, select documents and create binders for the target upskilling/reskilling concept or create binders by selecting all the recommendations. 

 

2) A library of ~20,000 resources on Computer Science/Technology topics. 

 

3) A highlighter tool for highlighting documents and keeping notes. 

 

4) A tool for looking up summaries of concepts, dictionary definitions or related documents that further explore the concept. 

 

5) A lexical substitution tool that highlights difficult words and offers simpler alternatives. These difficult words can be common but complex words that can be simplified by lexical substitution -- not concepts that require prerequisite knowledge in order to be understood.
